facts.text: Appeals numbered C. A. Nos. 1378 and 1379 of 1969

anchor.surface_text: C. A. Nos. 1378 and 1379 of 1969. Appeals by certificate from the judgment and order dated May 21, 1968 of the Calcutta High Court in Income-tax Reference No. 17 of 1965.

facts.text: Appeals by certificate from judgment and order dated May 21, 1968 of Calcutta High Court in Income-tax Reference No. 17 of 1965

anchor.surface_text: Appeals by certificate from the judgment and order dated May 21, 1968 of the Calcutta High Court in Income-tax Reference No. 17 of 1965. S. Desai, P. L. Juneja, R. N. Sachthey and S. P. Nayar, for the appellant.

facts.text: Question referred to High Court by Tribunal under s. 66 of Indian Income-tax Act, 1922

anchor.surface_text: The question that was referred to the High Court by the Tribunal under s. 66(1) of the Indian Income- tax Act, 1922 hereinafter called. the Act  is as follows Whether, on the facts and in the circumstances of the case,

facts.text: High Court answered the question in the affirmative and against the department

anchor.surface_text: The High Court has answered that question in the affirmative and against the department following the reasoning which was obiter in the case of Moore Avenue Properties Private Ltd. v. C.I.T. [59 I.T.R. 466].

facts.text: Respondent is a private company to which sub-s.(1) of s.23-A would be attracted if conditions fulfilled

anchor.surface_text: The respondent is a private company to which- it is not dis- puted, sub-s.(1) of s.23-A would be attracted if it fulfilled the conditions prescribed therein.

facts.text: Assessment years 1958-59 and 1959-60

anchor.surface_text: The assessment relating to which the Income--tax Officer sought to exercise his jurisdiction under that section was for the years 1958- 59 and 1959-60 for which the accounting year ended on 30th June 1957 and 30th June 1958 respectively.

facts.text: Accounting year for 1958-59 ended on 30th June 1957

anchor.surface_text: for the years 1958- 59 and 1959-60 for which the accounting year ended on 30th June 1957 and 30th June 1958 respectively. The order of the Income-tax Officer was dated October 31, 1961.

anchor.surface_text: respectively. The order of the Income-tax Officer was dated October 31, 1961. The contention of the appellant is that the company had, declared the dividends after the 12 months following the accounting year and hence the Income-tax Officer had with the previous sanction

facts.text: Company declared dividends after 12 months following the accounting year

anchor.surface_text: The contention of the appellant is that the company had, declared the dividends after the 12 months following the accounting year and hence the Income-tax Officer had with the previous sanction of the Inspecting Assistant Commis- sioner, validly subjected the company to super-tax

facts.text: Company declared Rs. 15,000 as dividend at general meeting on December 17, 1959

anchor.surface_text: This submission was rejected by the Income-tax Officer who sought to assess the respondent by including Rs. 15,000 and Rs. 90,000/- declared as dividends at the general meetings held on December 17, 1959 and May 26, 1960 in respect of the relevant assessment years.

facts.text: Company declared Rs. 90,000 as dividend at general meeting on May 26, 1960

anchor.surface_text: who sought to assess the respondent by including Rs. 15,000 and Rs. 90,000/- declared as dividends at the general meetings held on December 17, 1959 and May 26, 1960 in respect of the relevant assessment years. An appeal to the Appellate Assistant Commissioner was unsuccessful.

facts.text: Dividends declared in respect of assessment years 1958-59 and 1959-60

anchor.surface_text: Rs. 90,000/- declared as dividends at the general meetings held on December 17, 1959 and May 26, 1960 in respect of the relevant assessment years. An appeal to the Appellate Assistant Commissioner was unsuccessful.

facts.text: Appeal to Appellate Assistant Commissioner was unsuccessful

anchor.surface_text: in respect of the relevant assessment years. An appeal to the Appellate Assistant Commissioner was unsuccessful. The Tribunal however on a reading of the relevant parts of the section came to the conclusion

facts.text: Tribunal held that dividends actually distributed are to be deducted in computing undistributed balance

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal however on a reading of the relevant parts of the section came to the conclusion that in computing the undistributed balance of the total income not only the income-tax and super-tax payable by the company but also any other tax levied by the local authority ,etc. are to be deducted but also dividends actually distributed, if any

facts.text: Tribunal directed that Rs. 15,000 and Rs. 90,000 be taken into account in arriving at undistributed balance

anchor.surface_text: It was also of the view that no time limit was applicable in taking into account the actual distribution of dividends in passing an order under s. 23-A(1) by the- Income-tax Officer as such it directed that the sums of Rs. 15,000 and 90,000/- were to be taken into account in arriving at the undistributed balance of the total income of the respondent company

facts.text: Income-tax Officer made order under s.23A with previous sanction of Inspecting Assistant Commissioner

anchor.surface_text: and hence the Income-tax Officer had with the previous sanction of the Inspecting Assistant Commis- sioner, validly subjected the company to super-tax in terms of the latter part of s. 23-A(1). On behalf of the respondent it was submitted that once dividends were declared before an order is made under this section no super-tax can be levied in respect of those dividends.

facts.text: Respondent submitted that once dividends declared before order under s.23A, no super-tax can be levied

anchor.surface_text: On behalf of the respondent it was submitted that once dividends were declared before an order is made under this section no super-tax can be levied in respect of those dividends. This submission was rejected by the Income-tax Officer who sought to assess the respondent by including Rs. 15,000 and Rs. 90,000/-

facts.text: Supreme Court holds High Court was right in answering the question in the affirmative

anchor.surface_text: In this view, we think the High Court was right in answering the question in the affirmative.

facts.text: Section 23A(1) applies to companies in which public are not substantially interested

anchor.surface_text: This provision is procedural and applies only to companies in which the public are not substantially interested. It seems to have been enacted with a view to deter private companies which do not distribute more than 60% of their assessable income

facts.text: S.23A recast by Finance Act of 1955

anchor.surface_text: Before considering the contention on behalf of the revenue it will be necessary to examine the terms of the section and the object for which it was enacted. S.23-A(1) after it was recast by the Finance Act of 1955 is as follows -
s. 66 1  of the Indian Income- tax Act, 1922

anchor.surface_text: S. 23-A 1  of the Income-tax Act, 1922, the Income-tax Officer should have taken into companysideration dividend declared by the companypany after the period of 12 months

concepts.interpretation: Dividends declared after 12 months but before ITO order under this section must be considered in computing undistributed balance for super-tax

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: deter private companypanies which do number distribute more than 60 of their assessable income on pain of exposing them to the drastic companysequence

concepts.unlisted_description: Super-tax on undistributed balance of closely held companies if dividends less than statutory percentage

anchor.surface_text: sub-s.(1) of s.23-A would be attracted if it fulfilled the companyditions prescribed therein.

concepts.unlisted_description: Super-tax on undistributed balance of closely held companies if dividends less than statutory percentage

anchor.surface_text: S.23-A 1  after it was recast by the Finance Act of 1955 is as follows - Where the Income-tax Officer is satisfied that in respect of any previous year the profits and gains distributed as dividends by any companypany within the twelve months- immediately following the expiry of that pre- vious year are less than the statutory percentage of the total income of the companypany of that previous year as reduced by-  a the amount of income-tax and super-tax payable by the companypany in respect of its total income, but ex- cluding the amount of any super-tax payable under this section  b the amount of any other tax levied under any law for the time being in force on the companypany by the Government or by a local authority in excess of the amount, if any, which has been allowed in companyputing the total income and  c in the case of a banking companypany, the amount actually transferred to a reserve fund under s.17 of the Banking Companies Act, 1949 the Income-tax Officer shall, unless he is satisfied that, having regard to the losses incurred by the companypany in earlier years or to the smallness of the profits made in the previous year, the payment of a dividend or a larger dividend than that declared would be unreasonable, make an order in writing that the companypany shall, apart from the sum determined as payable by it on the basis of the assessment under section 23, be liable to pay super-tax at the rate of fifty per cent in the case of a companypany whose business companysists wholly or mainly in the dealing in or holding of investments, and at the rate of thirty-seven per cent in the case of any other companypany on the undistributed balance of the total income of the previous year, that is to say, on the total amount as reduced by the amounts, if any, referred to in clause  a , clause  b  or clause  c  and the dividends actually distributed, if any.

issues.text: Whether, on the facts and in the circumstances of the case, the Tribunal was right in holding that in the matter of calculation of undistributed balance of the total income of an assessee for the purpose of levy of super-tax in terms of S. 23-A(1) of the Income-tax Act, 1922, the Income-tax Officer should have taken into consideration dividend declared by the company after the period of 12 months immediately following the expiry of the previous years relevant to the assessment years 1958-59 and 1959-60 but before the date on which the orders under S. 23-A(1) had been made by the Income-tax Officer?

anchor.surface_text: Whether, on the facts and in the circumstances of the case, the Tribunal was right in holding that in the matter of calculation of undistributed balance of the total income of an assessee for the purpose of levy of super-tax in terms of S. 23-A 1  of the Income-tax Act, 1922, the Income-tax Officer should have taken into companysideration dividend declared by the companypany after the period of 12 months

arguments.claim: Company declared dividends after the 12 months following the accounting year, so Income-tax Officer validly subjected company to super-tax under s.23A(1)

anchor.surface_text: The contention of the appellant is that the company had, declared the dividends after the 12 months following the accounting year and hence the Income-tax Officer had with the previous sanction of the Inspecting Assistant Commis- sioner, validly subjected the company to super-tax

arguments.court_reasoning: Dividends actually distributed before ITO order must be deducted; otherwise undistributed balance exceeds commercial profits and leads to double taxation

arguments.claim: Once dividends declared before order under s.23A, no super-tax can be levied in respect of those dividends

anchor.surface_text: On behalf of the respondent it was submitted that once dividends were declared before an order is made under this section no super-tax can be levied in respect of those dividends. This submission was rejected by the Income-tax Officer

arguments.court_reasoning: Text supports deducting actually distributed dividends; avoids illogical results like exceeding commercial profits and double taxation

arguments.claim: In computing undistributed balance under s.23A(1), deduct dividends actually distributed if any, even after 12 months, as no time limit applies

arguments.court_reasoning: Agrees with plain language and logic preventing excess assessment and double tax

arguments.claim: S.23A(1) enacted to deter private companies from not distributing at least 60% of assessable income, preventing shareholder tax avoidance via accumulation

anchor.surface_text: This provision is procedural and applies only to companies in which the public are not substantially interested. It seems to have been enacted with a view to deter private companies which do not distribute more than 60% of their assessable income

arguments.claim: ITO has jurisdiction under s.23A(1) only if at time of order, dividends within 12 months < statutory percentage

anchor.surface_text: In cases where the provisions have not been complied with, the Income-tax Officer with the previous approval and consent of the Inspecting Assistant Commissioner will get jurisdiction to make an order if at the time of the passing of the order it is found that the company has not distributed by way of dividends within twelve months

arguments.claim: ITO cannot levy super-tax under s.23A if dividend declared before order, as undistributed balance would exceed commercial profits and cause double taxation

anchor.surface_text: Though the Income-tax Officer has jurisdiction to pass an order under sub-s.(1) he has to make a regular assessment on the company under S. 23 which he cannot do if in fact a dividend had been declared before the making of that order, as otherwise the companyâ€™s undistributed balance which is assessed by the Income-tax Officer would exceed its commercial profits. There is also a likelihood of double taxation

arguments.claim: Company declares dividends from profits in general meeting; if declared and paid before ITO order, no s.23A assessment possible despite non-fulfilment of 12-month condition

anchor.surface_text: As the company can only declare dividends in general meeting from the profits earned by it, and when that is declared and paid the Income-tax Officer though for the non-fulfilment of the conditions prescribed in the section may seek to reopen it he cannot make an assessment in cases where the dividend has actually been declared and paid before the date of his order

arguments.claim: High Court correctly answered question affirmatively against department, following obiter reasoning in Moore Avenue Properties case

anchor.surface_text: The High Court has answered that question in the affirmative and against the department following the reasoning which was obiter in the case of Moore Avenue Properties Private Ltd. v. C.I.T. [59 I.T.R. 466].

arguments.court_reasoning: Agrees with High Court's view based on own interpretation

holdings.text: In this view, we think the High Court was right in answering the question in the affirmative.

anchor.surface_text: In this view, we think the High Court was right in answering the question in the affirmative.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual interpretation of s.23A(1) mandates deduction of dividends actually distributed before ITO order; refusal leads to undistributed balance exceeding commercial profits and double taxation, contrary to intent.

holdings.text: In cases where the provisions have not been complied with, the Income-tax Officer with the previous approval and consent of the Inspecting Assistant Commissioner will get jurisdiction to make an order if at the time of the passing of the order it is found that the company has not distributed by way of dividends within twelve months immediately following the accounting year less than the statutory percentage of its total income of the accounting year as reduced by the amount of taxes payable by the company.

anchor.surface_text: In cases where the provisions have not been complied with, the Income-tax Officer with the previous approval and consent of the Inspecting Assistant Commis- sioner will get jurisdiction to make an order if at the time of the passing of the order it is found that the company has not distributed by way of dividends within twelve months

holdings.reasoning_summary: Jurisdiction determined at time of ITO order based on whether 12-month dividends fall below statutory percentage after reductions.

holdings.text: Though the Income-tax Officer has jurisdiction to pass an order under sub-s.(1) he has to make a regular assessment on the company under S. 23 which he cannot do if in fact a dividend had been declared before the making of that order, as otherwise the companyâ€™s undistributed balance which is assessed by the Income-tax Officer would exceed its commercial profits. There is also a likelihood of double taxation.

anchor.surface_text: Though the Income-tax Officer has jurisdiction to pass an order under sub-s.(1) he has to make a regular assessment on the company under S. 23 which he cannot do if in fact a dividend had been declared before the making of that order, as otherwise the company

holdings.reasoning_summary: Even with jurisdiction, computation under s.23A must harmonize with regular assessment under s.23; ignoring pre-order dividends causes illogical excess over commercial profits and double taxation.

holdings.text: As the company can only declare dividends in general meeting from the profits earned by it, and when that is declared and paid the Income-tax Officer though for the non-fulfilment of the conditions prescribed in the section may seek to reopen it he cannot make an assessment in cases where the dividend has actually been declared and paid before the date of his order.

anchor.surface_text: As the company can only declare dividends in general meeting from the profits earned by it, and when that is declared and paid the Income-tax Officer though for the non-fulfilment of the conditions prescribed in the section may seek to reopen it he cannot make an assessment in cases where the dividend has actually been declared and paid before the date of his order.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Dividends declared and paid pre-order preclude s.23A super-tax assessment despite 12-month non-compliance, as actual distribution reduces undistributed balance to zero or appropriate level.

precedents.cited_proposition: In calculating undistributed balance for super-tax under s. 23A(1), Income-tax Officer must consider dividends declared after 12 months from expiry of previous year but before the order under s. 23A(1)
